docs.lead_paragraph: Ever since he was elected, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has derided New York's public hospitals and vowed to turn some of them over to private hospitals, which he says will provide the poor with better care and save the city money. Three hospitals are on the auction block and the administration predicts a deal this summer. But as the Mayor and his advisers try to spin off large chunks of the system to the private sector, so far unsuccessfully, critics say they have so neglected the hospitals that patient services and building conditions are worse than at any time in recent years.

headline.main: Mayor's Stalled Plans Leave Public Hospitals in Trauma

docs.section_name: Front Page; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: U.S. Healthcare was ordered by a Federal jury yesterday to pay $1.2 million in damages to a smaller company that had accused the big health maintenance organization of violating antitrust laws by forcing retail pharmacies to buy employee coverage from it. The jury, in its verdict in a civil lawsuit in Philadelphia, found that U.S. Healthcare and three senior executives were liable under Federal antitrust and racketeering laws and a Pennsylvania law on contracts. The suit was brought by Brokerage Concepts Inc., a privately held insurance broker that also runs self-insured health plans.

headline.main: Antitrust Suit Goes Against Big H.M.O.

docs.lead_paragraph: The London Life Insurance Company said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Canadian branch operations of the Prudential Insurance Company of America for about $100 million (Canadian), or $73 million (U.S.). London Life will acquire Prudential's Canadian life insurance, group life and health, pension, annuity and mutual fund businesses, which have total assets of $4.2 billion (Canadian). London Life, a financial services concern based in London, Ontario, will have assets of $19.4 billion (Canadian) after the transaction.

headline.main: CANADIAN OPERATIONS OF PRUDENTIAL TO CHANGE HANDS

docs.lead_paragraph: Hunterdon County reported 565 cases of Lyme disease last year, one of the highest rates in the country. The Senate Health Committee will meet in Flemington today to consider legislation to require health insurance companies to cover treatment for the disease for as long as medically necessary. If a second opinion is required, a doctor could be selected from a list of those familiar with the disease. Now, insurance companies frequently discontinue coverage for Lyme disease treatment after 26 days.

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Arnold Holzman, a psychologist in Hamden, Conn., thought he was making progress with his patient, an upper-level manager in his 50's, who came into therapy only after his wife threatened to leave him if he did not learn to control his temper. It had taken some time before the man trusted Dr. Holzman enough to talk about his anger, depression and the childhood abuse he had suffered. So Dr. Holzman worried what would happen to that trust last year, when he told the patient that the managed care company paying for the treatment was coming to inspect his files.

headline.main: A LOSS OF CONFIDENCE: A special report.;Questions of Privacy Roil Arena of Psychotherapy

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re "H.M.O.'s Cope With a Backlash on Cost Cutting" (front page, May 19): All state efforts to regulate abuses of managed care organizations are fated to be in vain for most managed care patients -- those, that is, whose membership is provided through their employers.

docs.lead_paragraph: In the latest example of a fast-growing national trend, Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New Jersey and its Delaware counterpart announced yesterday that they would combine operations by the end of August. The combination will help companies who have employees in more than one state and will enable Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New Jersey to compete more effectively with at least two other big health insurance companies in the Philadelphia region, according to William J. Marino, the chairman and chief executive of the New Jersey program.

headline.main: Blue Cross to Combine New Jersey and Delaware Operations
